headline.main: Will the Spirit Of the Twinkie Live On?

docs.abstract: Clyde Haberman NYC column comments on growing girth of his fellow New Yorkers (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: NOT to offend anyone, but a subway ride yesterday made it amply clear how clearly ample many New Yorkers are. This is hardly a thunderbolt observation. Still, a journey on a train with contoured seats is a good reminder that you live in Fat City. Watching six people struggle to fit comfortably into a space ostensibly designed for eight is not a pretty sight.
docs.snippet: A journey on a train with contoured seats is a good reminder that you live in Fat City.

keywords.value: CENTER FOR SCIENCE IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST
keywords.name: organizations

headline.main: All Is Not Sweet at the Home Base of Coca-Cola

docs.abstract: Market Place column on turmoil at Coca-Cola Co's Atlanta home base; analysts say infighting between top executives and powerful directors like Donald R Keough, and among top executives themselves, has spurred excessive executive turnover; lower ranks at Coke are also in turmoil; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In late June, just a few weeks after coming out of retirement to become the Coca-Cola Company's latest chief executive, E. Neville Isdell visited Coke's regional managers in China. He remembers one in particular, a young woman named Lily, on the job less than three years and radiating zeal and spunk. ''She reminded me of myself at her age, just full of enthusiasm for the business and the brand,'' Mr. Isdell, 61, said. Fast-forward to Sept. 15, the day Coke warned investors that this year's earnings would be lower than they had expected. Mr. Isdell walked through Coke's Atlanta headquarters, and the miasma of gloom was palpable. ''No one would make eye contact with me,'' he recalled. ''The trust has been broken, and the culture needs regeneration.''
docs.snippet: Neville Isdell, the new chief executive of Coca-Cola, must lead a company whose motherland is in turmoil.

headline.main: Of Mice, Men and 'Magic' Diet Supplements

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses conjugated linoleic acid, unsaturated fatty acid that occurs naturally in milk and meat of animals, and its reported impact on weight loss and muscle building; CLA was first studied in 1978 by Dr Michael W Pariza, University of Wisconsin food scientist who suggested that it could promote overall better health; studies on nutrient are contradictory and suggest that although CLA has potential benefits, current health risks outweigh benefits of using supplements; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: With ephedra off the shelves and low-fat and low-carb diets getting you nowhere, you might be tempted to turn to a supplement called conjugated linoleic acid, or C.L.A., that has received an increasing amount of attention both in scientific and lay circles in recent years. The supplement has been widely promoted in alternative medicine circles and on the Internet as an aid to weight loss and muscle building and as a deterrent to heart disease, diabetes and cancer.
docs.snippet: The evidence on conjugated linoleic acid, a supplement that has received an increasing amount of attention in recent years, is far from clear.

headline.main: The Nation:  Health Care Costs Are a Killer, but Maybe That's a Plus

docs.abstract: Health care economists say main reason health care spending is rising is that modern medical technology has made it possible to do more for more people; say millions of people are being treated for ailments that went untreated or undetected years ago; say that spells more operations and more pills, and costs pile up; photo (M)
docs.section_name: Technology; Science; Health; Week in Review
docs.lead_paragraph: THE nation's health care bill is high and headed higher. Yet most hospitals lose money or barely break even. Doctors complain they are getting squeezed. Employers bemoan rising health care costs as a threat to global competitiveness. Then there are people like Dr. Thomas J. Fogarty, whose career is testimony to the entrepreneurial opportunity of high-tech medicine in America. He got his introduction to medicine as an eighth grader when he worked part time at the Good Samaritan Hospital in Cincinnati, cleaning stomach pumps and stacking bedpans. Soon, he was made a scrub technician so he saw a lot of surgery firsthand as teenager.
docs.snippet: The technological marvels of medicine mean that the insured majority are being treated for ailments that went untreated or undetected years ago.

headline.main: Marvin Davis, Oil Billionaire Who Bought And Then Sold Fox Studios, Is Dead at 79

docs.abstract: Marvin H Davis, billionaire who amassed fortune though well-timed deals in oil and entertainment industries, dies at age 79; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Marvin H. Davis, a billionaire who amassed his fortune through well-timed deals in the oil and entertainment industries, died yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., a family spokesman said. He was 79. Mr. Davis died of natural causes, said the spokesman, Michael Sitrick. Friends said that Mr. Davis, who was six feet four and weighed 300 pounds, had long suffered from heart trouble, back pain, diabetes and other effects of morbid obesity.
docs.snippet: In 2004, Forbes magazine listed Marvin Davis as the 30th richest person in the United States, estimating his wealth at $5.8 billion.

headline.main: Facing an Armada of Patatas in Spain

docs.abstract: Neil Gladstone travel essay on plethora of carbohydrate-filled foods available at restaurants, snack bars and fast-food spots during visit to Madrid and Seville; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: MY girlfriend, Wendy, and I were strolling along a street in Madrid, trying to find the Palacio Real when a snack bar marquee caught my eye: ''Churros y Patatas.'' Loosely translated, the phrase means ''cellulite for your pasty thighs.''
docs.snippet: Searching for low-carb food, a visitor finds that bread and other starches are alive and well, and so are the residents.
